children.subject:
I'll see what I can do in a future post. Quick note: You'll always find people complaining about something and they assume it's a general issue. For example, weather may be mildly "hot" or "cold", but some people will think it's "super hot", while others are fine. I can wear a T-shirt in Berkeley weather year round, while someone else will need 2 layers of jackets. If someone says "Berkeley weather is freezing", this isn't the case for everyone.

I use this analogy because it's the same with housing. Some people say "housing is scarce and expensive" because it is for them. I don't think housing is too hard to find at Berkeley.

Find 3-4 people and see if you can rent a house/apartment. Ask seniors/juniors/sophomores if you can take their place next year. Go on the 3-4 UC Berkeley housing pages on Facebook. Go to club specific groups and ask your club peers. If you start doing that right now, you'll be flooded with opportunities for housing.

I've had a friend paying $500 for a double because they crammed 5 people in a cheap 3 bedroom. I know people paying $800 for a double, and people paying $1200 for a double. I know people who are paying $600 for singles(Co-Ops, apply right now), and $2500 for their own apartment.

I'd say explore the market, educate yourself by asking your peers, and have your pick.

If your budget is $500 or something, look into a triple or living room. Not ideal, housing is tough and I respect that...but you have to live somewhere while at school :)

My absolute #1 tip for finding housing you'll be fulfilled in is to start asking people right now if you can take their spot next year. A lot of times(depending on the friendship), people won't have an answer, so you ask a lot of people.

"Hey bob, ur living in XYZ knowYourRoleBoulevard right now? What's it like? Oh, it's awesome? That's good to hear. Is it safe? Oski Safe? Great to hear. Hey dude, i'm lowkey afraid of getting housing next year, since ur graduating, do you know if there's a chance I could snag that spot for next year?"

I can't say how people will respond. If it were me, i'd say yes because I don't care who lives in my space once I move out lol. If I can help a friend alleviate their stress by giving them my spot for next year, i'd do it.
seriously look into the Berkeley Student Cooperative!!! rent is less than like 750 a month and that includes meals, utilities, etc. you gotta apply asap if you want any chance tho
I'm kind of stressed about housing. It is expensive and scarce. I saw at UCSC they are asking professors to house students in their own homes.

Sorry to hear about the stressing out, definitely check out my other posts and try to internalize the information into mindsets and actions...but it can be tough. I feel there's so many more scenarios to discuss. You're not alone, and as a result, you have all of us to be there for you.

I don't take life too seriously so i'm always in the mood to joke around lol. It's fun to smile and laugh ya know? :)
Stressed about a million things, but the lighthearted tone of this post made me chuckle.

hi there. it sounds like you like writing software. remember that no one can take that away from you - regardless of company rejections, bad cs grades, etc - no one can stop you from doing what you love.

also, thank you farid for bringing attention to mental health in our department - i’m sure you’re helping a lot of people out :)

I'm doing wonderful, thanks for asking :)

I think it's important to keep in mind how talented our peers are, whether it's from years of coding and developing skills, hard work in the past that led to their ability to learn quickly, or maybe genetics and parents play a factor. As I said in a previous post, millions of reasons people are interning at Google as a sophomore and you're not.

I know you're not comparing yourself to others, but 1 component to not comparing yourself with others includes NOT COMPARING TIMELINES. It's cool that sally is interning at Google and she's your peer, but just know you can work at Google in 2 years, 5 years, 10 years, 50 years, w/e.

I will see if I can make another post about careers, but i'll say this: If you spend everyday working on your CS skills, you'll get somewhere. If you feel decent as an Engineer but aren't getting interviews, you should work on resume, pitch, and method of applying.

You WILL SUCCEED because you ARE SUCCEEDING. You're at UC Berkeley studying (EE?)CS, you're doing awesome. If you never give up, one day you'll be working at a company, and if you never give up, one day you'll work at your dream company doing your dream thing.
Thanks 2nd anon :) I think you're awesome for giving advice to 1st anon

How are you doing Farid? You've made a lot of these, probably done a lot of good for the mental health of countless CS/EECS majors on this forum and many others. I know from personal experience that people can have trouble following their own advice, so I just wanna make sure you're listening to yourself too :)

That said my biggest stressor is probably still career stuff... not that I'm feeling pressure from friends or family or anything, just from myself. My vision for after college has always been to land a nice stable SWE job and live the lifestyle I want to. I've always been a computer/software kind of guy and have been led down this path by many events in life, so I really hadn't considered anything else... But now that I'm seeing how godawfully competitive every single position is, I'm having doubts about whether that's gonna pan out for me at all. I'm taking care of myself fine (sleep, food, exercise), have good grades, even tried my hands at a few pet projects and put them on GitHub, but nothing's worked out so far...

history.content:
Hey everyone,

I'm glad to know these posts are helping people. The topics I pick each week are random but depend on current student climate and what I notice students stress about. For example, I think now is the time clubs have selected people, so when i'm free, I will write a post specifically for clubs.

If you have a certain topic you want covered, let me know in the follow ups below. It doesn't have to be CS specific(examples: stressed about lack of food, dating, weight, missing family, UCLA > Cal, etc). With that being said, I can also talk about CS specifics(examples: stressed about being rejected from CS, office hours too full, not getting into classes, feeling inadequate compared to people who interned at Google at the age of 3, etc).
history.subject: "Stressed About ........" Requests?
